title: Insects and DNA metabarcoding - InsectMobile laboratory protocols
title_html: Insects and DNA metabarcoding - InsectMobile laboratory protocols

source.description:
Purify the
aliquots in the QIASymphony robot. 24 samples can be purified each time and always include one extraction blank aliquot as a robot blank. The robot runs 24 samples in one hour. The protocol draws on the following resources:
·DNA Handbook: EN-QIAsymphony-DNA-Handbook.pdf
·Low content purification protocol: HB-0977-S09_002_PS_QS_LowHighContent_V7_DSP_DNA_UV_0818_WW.pdf
·General description of the QIASymphony SP/AS robot: QIASymphony_SPAS_GeneralDescription.pdf
·User manual: QIAsymphony_SPAS_User_Manual_Operating_the_QIAsymphony_SP_1211.pdf

General information

  • 200 µl tip boxes for QIACube works in QIASymphony (QS), but not the 1000 µl tips. QIASymphony uses 1500 µl tips (Cat No./ID: 997024)
  • On QIAGEN’s webpage search for instrument for instrument information and kit for kit information
  • On the specific kit webpage, one can find handbooks for the kit under the tab ‘ressources’
  • The document called ‘labware test’ shows, which protocol and labware are recommended for a specific application/kit. Green = good, Yellow = has not been tested, red = not recommended
  • QIAGEN can help with a custom protocol if a custom elution is required
  • Every time you open the hood the machine asks you whether you have changed anything
  • Tip chute can be cleaned with normal dishwashing detergent if needed
  • Drop catchers should be checked occasionally for spillage and cleaned with dishwashing detergent and 70% EtOH if needed
  • Tips tend to stack in the waste bag and this can cause malfunction, so kick the bag occasionally to make sure they are evenly distributed
  • DO NOT USE EtOH ON PLEXIGLASS & THE SCREEN!
  • Change the O-rings every month to keep the pipetting precise
  • You can work in the next drawer while the machine checks the previous drawer
All catalog numbers are according to QIAGENS webpage (26.11.2018).

source.description: When loading the robot you always go from the end (elution) to the beginning (samples) (right to left).
Choose the tab ‘Sample preparation’ for running samples

An adaptor = a cooling rack and you use EMTR plates for eluation (96 tubes/samples, deep-well (special tube racks required)) OR single tubes (24 samples). Elution slot 1 is the only slot with cooling.
If you use single tubes, label them and place them in the rack without lids on

When placing the cooling rack, make sure the marked ‘A’ on the plate is placed at the ‘A’ mark on the drawer – THIS IS IMPORTANT for knowing which samples are which and the old racks can be placed both ways. For 96 plates: When the bottom is removed from the rack the lid should be on

Adaptor holes in the bottom show how it should be placed on slot 1 (=cold,
)
Press ‘ID’ and register the type of rack you are using - use the document ‘labware test’ because the plate should match the adaptor and to run properly the robot needs to know which type it is
Press ‘Rack ID’ to give the rack a name
Press ‘OK’. Now the system will check whether the drawer has been loaded correctly
Make sure there are waste buckets in the empty slots and remove the lid from partially filled waste buckets
Make sure there is room in the bag for used tips. Waste drawer layout:
Press ‘OK’. The robot will check the ‘Waste’ drawer and the bucket closest to you, which needs to be empty if the machine is turned off. If the bucket is full then place a lid on it and throw it out

You can run two kits, even different kits, at the same time. The robot will let you know prior to a run, whether you need to load more consumables, based on the number of samples. When restocking consumables, use the whole unit box to minimize the risk of contamination. You can scan specific slots for the drawer, which comes in handy if you only make changes to e.g. tip stocks.
Load tips, cartridges and rod covers, if needed.

source.description: Make sure the orientation of the tip holders is correct. You do not need to put tips in a specific slot for the machine to work.
Vortex the beads trough for min. 3 minutes to re-suspend the beads. The lid can be greasy when you take it off, and make sure to wipe the barcode of if it is dirty, so the machine can read it
Follow the protocol in the kit. If the reagents are unused, a piercing lid has to be placed on the reagent cartridge. Be careful – the piercing lid is sharp
The original lid can be re-used to hold the sealing lids if you are re-using a reagent cartridge
Mount the enzyme rack on the side of the reagent cartridge. Lids can be placed in the holders below the enzyme rack
Load the reagent cartridge
Let the robot check whether you loaded the drawer correctly. This check takes a long time (5-10 min)

The robot uses four-channel pipettes, so make sure everything is loaded in four, e.g. if you have vials of different size, then they need to be loaded in fours. The 3B adapter in the sample racks is used for the Sarstedt microtubes.

source.name: Micro tube 2ml, PP
source.type: Screw Cap Micro Tube, 2 ml, PP, with skirted base, with knurls, with assembled cap, with printed writing space and graduation, sterile, 100 pcs./bag

source.description: Remove the lids from the sample tube and place them in the sample rack. NOTE THE ORDER OF THE SAMPLES
Load the sample rack in a lane by supporting the rack below with one hand and slide the rack to the first line and wait until the camera comes out

When the light blinks, push the rack steadily into the robot and make sure the robot has registered all the tubes (this step take practice and you might need to reload it several times). The robot tells you if you need to reload the samples
Choose the batch on the screen to assign names to your samples and specify the protocol and vial type
Select all samples and assign the tube type. We use the vial holder 3B and the tubes are called Sarstedt screw skirted 72.694(.006)
Unless you use a barcode reader, you will need to manually assign names to each sample in the system. Choose each sample and press ‘sample id’ to assign a name
Choose your setup and which protocol you use (InsectMobile uses ‘DNA Tissue LC’). Press “Next”
Press “Queue” and then “Run”
The robot might tell you that you need to load more tips, rod covers or sample prep cartridges. You can specify which consumables that that should be scanned after you make the changes
If you use the USB stick, then transfer the run file by pressing “Tools”→”User Management”→”File transfer”→”Save to USB”→”Results file”→”Transfer”

source.title: Diluting DNA for standard input in PCR

source.description:
Quantify the DNA concentration in each sample with QuBit HS (BR if too high).
Use the template to calculate how much DNA and molecular grade water should be used for a final volume of
with an approximate DNA concentration of
Make the dilutions in 8-strip PCR tubes and include a blank (molecular grade water) in every 6th row. PCRs can then be carried out for full libraries of 96 samples in each library.
Materials needed
  • Molecular grade water aliquot
  • PCR strips
  • 20 ul or 200 ul empty tip container for holding strips
  • Permanent marker for writing on PCR tubes (IM_numbers)
  • 10 or 20 ul tips
  • 200 ul tips
  • 200 and 20/10 ul pipettes
  • Rack for water aliquot

source.name: Invitrogen™ Qubit™ 3 Fluorometer
source.type: Accurately measures DNA, RNA, and protein using the highly sensitive fluorescence-based Qubit quantitation assays

source.title: Diluting DNA for standard input in PCR

source.description: In the “Dilutions” sheet input the PCRID and associated QuBit measurement. Input HS if this worked otherwise input BR.

source.title: Diluting DNA for standard input in PCR

source.description: If your sample is too low for QuBit to perform a measurement then put the final volume in the column DNA added

source.title: Diluting DNA for standard input in PCR

source.description:
Generally, we want a final volume of
. However, this is not always possible. If you sample measurement is below
but it is not too low, then still treat it as a too low sample and add the finale volume in the column DNA added

source.title: Diluting DNA for standard input in PCR

source.description: If your sample has a very high DNA concentration then you need to increase the finale volume → try to get the volume around 1 in the column DNA added

When the samples have been extracted, purified, measured with Qubit and diluted to 2 ng/µL, they are ready to be amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Ideally, PCR setup prior to DNA input should be carried out in a DNA-free lab. We set up the MM and add the tagged primers in the DNA-free prior to adding the 2 ng/µL sample in DNA lab.
Setup your PCR spreadsheet prior to entering the lab and print it. It should contain the tag combination of your primers for each tube, which samples go in each tube and the calculated reaction volume of Master Mix (MM). See attached example of PCR spreadsheets setup and thermocycler settings. Example setup for the fwh primer pair (COI):
, example setup for the art primer pair (COI):
, example setup for the ins primer pair (16S):
Remember to add a couple of samples to the sample size, so you make enough MM, e.g. if you have 24 samples add 2 more so you make MM for 26 samples. The tag combination of each sample allows us to identify the origin of the sample when we get our sequencing results, so it is important it is consistent or else we will not be able to identify the sample in the data analysis. Switch tag combination for each library by either jumping 8 tags on the reverse or the forward primer (be consistent), since it makes it easier using the multichannel pipette.

Materials needed

  • 70% EtOH
  • 1:20 Bleach
  • Waste bin
  • Pipette holder
  • Pipettes of the volume needed (see recipe/spreadsheet)
  • Multichannel pipette
  • Repeater (electronic pipette)
  • Pipette tip boxes that match the pipettes
  • Pipette tip for the repeater
  • Primers from the freezer
  • dNTPs in the correct dilution
  • BSA
  • MgCl2
  • PCR buffer
  • Tag Gold polymerase
  • Molecular grade H2O aliquot in 50 mL tube
  • PCR tubes in strips of 8 with individual lids
  • 2 x Eppendorf tubes for MM & H2O
  • Freezing rack for PCR buffer reagents, Master Mix (MM) and H2O

source.name: Ultrapure dNTPs as set of 100 mM. Stringent QC at ISO-certificated BULK-Production

source.description:
The first step prior to DNA extraction is to remove the insects from the sampling net, dry them, obtain biomass and then move on to DNA extraction. The general steps covered in this section are:
  1. Prepare labels
  2. Weigh empty tubes with labels
  3. Remove insects from the sampling net
  4. Dry insect samples
  5. Weigh the dry insects
  6. Sample digestion
  7. Extract digest and wash insects for sample preservation

12 samples (11 samples + 1 blank) NB. A maximum of 12 samples can be extracted each day (per person).
Make sure to make falcon tube labels for ‘ND extract’ and ‘ND extracted insects’, Microtube (Sarstedts 2 mL) labels for robot purification ‘QIASymphony aliquot’ and ‘QIASymphony purified DNA’ and four top labels for each sample (label size also fits Eppendorf tubes).
Prepare labels for print. Label example:
Designate and label tubes and weigh the empty tubes with labels standing on the lid – you will weigh them again after the insects have dried to get the dry weight of the sample

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description:
Clean the work area and laminar flow hood with1:10 diluted bleach and 70% ethanol. Sort insects in the laminar flow hood.

Material and reagents needed (day 1)

  • 1:20 Bleach for cleaning
  • 1 glass tub with spout for removal of insects from sampling net (can be substituted with plastic trays)
  • 70 & 96% EtOH
  • Forceps
  • Vacuum filtration device
  • Filters
  • Laminated mm paper for size sorting
  • 15/50 mL tubes for drying insects (label them with sample number and “<10” (S = small) or “>10” (L = large) for size)
  • Mask for respiratory protection during vacuum filtration
  • 1 glass tub with spout for removal of insects from sampling net (can be substituted with plastic trays)
  • 70 & 96% EtOH
  • Forceps
  • Vacuum filtration device
  • Filters
  • Laminated mm paper for size sorting
  • 15/50 mL tubes for drying insects (label them with sample number and “<10” (S = small) or “>10” (L = large) for size)
  • Mask for respiratory protection during vacuum filtration
  • Forceps
  • Vacuum filtration device
  • Filters
  • Laminated mm paper for size sorting
  • 15/50 mL tubes for drying insects (label them with sample number and “<10” (S = small) or “>10” (L = large) for size)
  • Mask for respiratory protection during vacuum filtration
  • Laminated mm paper for size sorting
  • 15/50 mL tubes for drying insects (label them with sample number and “<10” (S = small) or “>10” (L = large) for size)
  • Mask for respiratory protection during vacuum filtration

BLS half mask in silicone, twin filters with bayonet fitting

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description: Take a glass tub (with spout) and clean it with diluted bleach and 70% EtOH.

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description: Pour the 96% EtOH from the sample into the tub and place the tub on the laminated mm paper

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description: Take out a sample net and turn it inside out in the 96% EtOH in the glass tub. Most of the insects should let go when they come into contact with the ethanol

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description: Try dipping the net up and down to make as many insects let go as possible. Add 70% ethanol if needed.

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description: For the remaining insects, take a cleaned forceps (bleach + EtOH) and carefully remove them, releasing them into the 96% EtOH

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description: When all the insects are free from the net, rinse the net and let it dry.

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description:
Take out any insects that are above 10 mm – use the mm paper for picking them out. Make sure there is no smaller insects sticking to the larger insects. Place the larger insects in a separate falcon tube (
or
depending on how big they are). Each
tube should only contain max.
of insects and should be divided into two if they take up too much space.

source.title: Removal of insects from sample net (day 1)

source.description:
Work with mask to avoid fumes from ethanol and bleach - alternatively work under fume extractor.
The remaining insects in the ethanol are poured through a cleaned (bleach + EtOH) vacuum filtration device and the insects that remain on the use-once filter.
(i.e. the small size fraction) is transferred to sample tubes (
or
depending on amount)

source.name: BLS half mask in silicone, twin filters with bayonet fitting
Recyclable ABEK1P3 R multifilter, BLS 4000 series, double filter
Qualitative filter papers standard grades grade 4 and 4V Whatman™

source.description:
Samples (with no lids) are placed in an oven at
to dry. The fan should be off inside oven (if possible)! Lids are placed in a way to avoid contamination (e.g. within sheets of aluminium foil). Include a blank (an empty, open 15 mL tube) for each extraction day.
Check the samples roughly every hour. EtOH leaking out of the insects can be removed with a p1000 to speed up the drying process and enable further processing the same day.

When samples are dry (some samples may have ethanol residue almost impossible to get rid of) ad 'magic buffer' based on the original recipe:
and later modified here:
and lyse the samples. We use the modified version of the buffer.

Material and reagents needed (day 1 or 2)

  • 70% EtOH for cleaning
  • 1:20 Bleach for cleaning
  • Weight
  • Weighing boat
  • Magic Buffer stock aliquot (see references for recipe)
  • DTT
  • Proteinase K
  • P1000 pipette + tips

source.description: Clean the flow hood + pipette and pipette tip box prior to use
Note the volume of the dried insects + falcon tube type (mL)
Weigh the dry weight of the insects (biomass) in the falcon tube by placing the tube on its head in the center of the weight (mg).

Calculate how much buffer is needed for all samples:
The volume of insects in each tube +
buffer* (to ease the transfer of the supernatant), e.g. in sample a:
of dried insects +
buffer =
for sample a
*If there is less than
of insects in the tube, subtract the amount from the
total, e.g.
insects –
buffer =
buffer should be poured on the sample.
If there is <=
of 1-2 individuals of slim large insects (>=1 cm), add volume of insects +
buffer, e.g. in sample:
of 1 Syrphidae,
+
=
Add up the total amount of buffer need for all samples, and add 2 mL to the blank and prepare 1-2 extra mL to ensure you have enough buffer aliquot.
Take out an aliquot based on your calculation from the 500 mL stock in the fridge.

Calculate how much DTT is needed for the reaction, e.g.: (
buffer aliquot ·
) / 1000 =

Calculate how much Proteinase K is needed for the reaction, e.g.:
buffer aliquot ·
=

Add DTT and then Proteinase K and gently mix the reagents before adding it to the samples and make sure the DTT completely dissolved. A good trick is to add DTT first, then buffer, and Proteinase K in the end. This way the DTT dissolves quickly. Add the buffer amount calculated for each sample, e.g. sample a = 8 mL of the buffer aliquot.

Place the samples in a rotator and put the rotator in an oven at
overnight. The rotator speed is the lowest setting (10).

The supernatant is ready to be extracted from the insect samples. The insects should be preserved in 96% EtOH as bulk voucher samples.

Material and reagents needed (day 2 or 3)

  • 70% EtOH for cleaning
  • 1:20 Bleach for cleaning
  • Large centrifuge
  • p1000 pipette + p1000 tips
  • 5 mL Eppendorf tubes for supernatant
  • 2 mL Sarstedt for aliquot of supernatant for purification
  • 96% EtOH for conserving the insects
  • 1:20 Bleach for cleaning
  • Large centrifuge
  • p1000 pipette + p1000 tips
  • 5 mL Eppendorf tubes for supernatant
  • 2 mL Sarstedt for aliquot of supernatant for purification
  • 96% EtOH for conserving the insects
  • Large centrifuge
  • p1000 pipette + p1000 tips
  • 5 mL Eppendorf tubes for supernatant
  • 2 mL Sarstedt for aliquot of supernatant for purification
  • 96% EtOH for conserving the insects

source.name: Micro tube 2ml, PP
source.type: Screw Cap Micro Tube, 2 ml, PP, with skirted base, with knurls, with assembled cap, with printed writing space and graduation, sterile, 100 pcs./bag

source.description:
Spin samples (only small size fraction) in the large centrifuge for about
. This will separate the insects somewhat from the supernatant to ease removal of the digest. If you have many small insects, then try to centrifuge the sample tube at 4000 g for 3 min
.

Extract digest with p1000 pipette (or p200/20 if many small insects get stuck in the tips) into 5 mL tubes (if there is more than 5 mL digest then discard the rest). This is a tedious process, but do make sure that no insects are transferred to the supernatant.

Fill sample tube with insects with 96% EtOH up to
and leave them until you finished extracting digest from all samples.

Spin the samples (only small size fraction) in the large centrifuge for about
(if needed)

Remove 96% EtOH from the samples and completely fill the tube with fresh 96% EtOH. If the EtOH looks clear then you can store the sample in the box. The samples that remain blurry should be flushed several times until the EtOH looks clear – this is occasionally the case for the samples with many small insects were it was difficult to remove the supernatant.

Vortex + spin the supernatant. Centrifuge settings
.

Add
supernatant to sample tubes (2 mL Sarstedt tubes) for QIASymphony purification and prepare tubes with labels for the eluate.
Turn on the flow hood and clean the workbench during the startup of the flow hood
Clean the pipette holder and the pipettes needed
Clean the flow hood and place the pipettes, pipette holder and waste bin in the hood
Clean and place a freeze rack in the hood and place PCR reagents (buffers, dNTPs, BSA) in the freeze rack to thaw
Take 2 x 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes – 1 for MM and 1 for molecular grade H2O. Label them.
Fill the water tube with the water required for the PCR reaction and some extra for PCR negatives

Mix the MM. Remember to add TagGold second last and H2O last
SLOWLY PUM UP AND DOWN WHEN ADDING THE H2O TO MIX THE BUFFER
Take out the primers you need and place them in the first rack. The second rack is for the primer strips you are done with
Take out as many PCR strips as you need, place them in the freeze rack and close the lids
Label PCR strips. The PCR tubes should be labelled like this:
Transfer MM to each PCR tube with the repeater. The amount of MM depends on how much DNA is added – check the recipe (e.g. 1 mL pipette tip, 19 µL MM, 32 x)

Add primers to your PCR tubes. Use the multichannel pipette → place the first one on a tip and “rollover”” to get the rest of the tips. Make sure they all are fastened by rolling the pipette a bit from side to side while pressing down. First, add forward primers to all PCR tubes, then add the reverse primers
Put the PCR strips and the rest of the H2O aliquot in a ziplock bag and store them in the fridge while you clean your workspace
Take the ziplock bag and go to the DNA lab to add sample DNA

The PCR tubes have MM and tagged primers and are ready for DNA input in the DNA lab.

Materials needed

  • 70% EtOH
  • 1:20 Bleach
  • Waste bin
  • Multichannel pipette
  • 10 µL pipette tips
  • PCR tubes with MM and tagged primers
  • Freezing rack for PCR tube strips with MM and primers
  • 2 ng/µL DNA dilutions in PCR tube strips
  • Rack for 2 ng/µL DNA dilutions PCR strips
  • 1:20 Bleach
  • Waste bin
  • Multichannel pipette
  • 10 µL pipette tips
  • PCR tubes with MM and tagged primers
  • Freezing rack for PCR tube strips with MM and primers
  • 2 ng/µL DNA dilutions in PCR tube strips
  • Rack for 2 ng/µL DNA dilutions PCR strips
  • Waste bin
  • Multichannel pipette
  • 10 µL pipette tips
  • PCR tubes with MM and tagged primers
  • Freezing rack for PCR tube strips with MM and primers
  • 2 ng/µL DNA dilutions in PCR tube strips
  • Rack for 2 ng/µL DNA dilutions PCR strips
Turn on the flow hood and clean the workbench during the startup of the flow hood
Clean the pipette, tip box and racks
Clean the flow hood and place everything you need in the hood
Take out the DNA dilutions and allow them to thaw

When the DNA has thawed, vortex for ~
and spin them down for ~
Add DNA using the multichannel pipette and according to the spreadsheet recipe
Add some of the leftover PCR reaction H2O to the PCR blank(s)
Put the PCR strips and water back in the ziplock bag and store it in the fridge while you clean

Now the DNA has been added to your PCR reaction and you are ready to run the samples on the PCR machine.
Place your samples in a PCR machine and adjust the settings according to the recipe on the spreadsheet. The run usually takes
-
.

When there is ~
. left, go to the gel area and prepare gels (2% agarose) corresponding to the number of samples you have
When the run is complete and your gels have solidified, prepare a sheet of parafilm

Use the multichannel pipette to transfer
gel red rows corresponding to the number of strips/samples you have
Vortex and spin your samples
Put the gels in the gel chambers

Transfer
to the designated gel red droplets and mix the liquids by pumping up and down

SET THE PIPETTE TO
AND PIPETTE EVERYTHING UP
The first well and the last well should have ladder, so skip those

Starting from the second well, pipette the sample slowly into the bottom of the wells
DO NOT stab the gel! Gently feel your way to ease the tips into the wells. You can feel whether you are in the wells by slowly moving the pipette from side to side in the wells. You should feel the sidewalls of the wells if you are in the wells
When almost all liquid is out → lift the pipette and push almost all the way down → lift up the pipette slowly and suck in a bit before leaving the gel, to suck up any bubbles

Run the gel with settings: 130 V, 350 A,
.
Now you can take pictures of the gels. Remember to put a USB stick in the USB slot and make sure the UV light is off.
Turn on the machine and go to live mode
Pour ddH2O on the surface and gently place plastic foil over it to avoid bubbles forming between the surface and the plastic foil.
Remove the gel from the gel chambers and pour off as much TBE buffer as possible. Make sure the gel does not slide
Gently push the gel onto the plastic foil and avoid bubbles forming under the gel
Close the door and turn on the UV-light
Adjust the setting so band appear visible, but no red colour is on the screen (red = too much light). Make sure to keep the settings the same when taking pictures of multiple gels
Save a picture on the USB stick by pressing “Save” – it takes some time
Print a picture by pressing “Print”. Make sure the photo machine is on. Label the photo immediately, so you know which picture is which and so you have a reference for the picture on your USB stick
Turn off the UV-light
Throw out the plastic foil and gel
Wipe the surface from water
Turn off the machine and take your USB stick

Immediately go to your computer and label your photo files from the USB stick correctly and update your gel results on the spreadsheet, see example
Your PCR samples should be stored in the freezer for long time storage or in the fridge for short-time storage. DO NOT store samples in the fridge for more than a couple of days.

PCR products are now ready to be pooled into libraries for sequencing.
  • All lab work must be carried out in the flow hood.
  • Pool PCR products so your pools are equimolar.
  • Make sure the starting DNA concentration >
  • .
  • Spin your buffers down before using them.
  • Remember to take End Repair Mix 2 out of the freezer to thaw some time before beginning the library build
Make sure the starting DNA concentration >
.
  • Spin your buffers down before using them.
  • Remember to take End Repair Mix 2 out of the freezer to thaw some time before beginning the library build

Pool 96 samples with unique tag combinations, e.g.each tag only appears once on the forward and reverse primer - this should add up based on the PCR runs. This is to avoid tag jumps during sequencing. We pool the samples based on gel band strength, but you can use QuBit to check whether it corresponds to DNA concentration for a subset of samples before you begin. See example spreadsheet for pool setup

). If the sample volume is over ~
, then split the sample between two columns and combine them again after eluation (end volume =
).

description:
This document is a collection of laboratory protocols for the citizen science and DNA metabarcoding research project 'InsectMobile' at the Natural History Museum of Denmark/University of Copenhagen 2017-2021. The protocol(s) cover all methodological steps from sample pre-processing to library build for next-generation-sequencing on a HiSeq 4000 150 bp PE platform.
Samples are collected with car rooftop-mounted insect nets by citizen scientists in the month of June 2018-2020 and the detachable end of the net containing flying insects is shipped to the laboratories at the Natural History Museum of Denmark/GLOBE Institute in containers containing 96% ethanol.
The insects are then size sorted, the large size fraction is identified by morphology and counted, and the sample dry-weight is obtained after which the bulk samples are processed with a DNA metabarcoding protocol. Morphological identification of the insects is not covered by this protocol.
